content.body: wicked
I met annevk, fantasai, hakon, jens, and arron in one day.
hm, looks like something is checking in changes under me
it's causing my w3c-html upload script to fail
hey all
Hixie: did you figure out the problem?
I see a bunch of commits from mike marked [updated by splitter]
MikeSmith: your temporary workaround for the bug in anolis is affecting unrelated parts of the spec
it's also affecting my checking in, but i've worked around that by just forcing the checkin each time
in my script
Hixie: OK, I'll turn it off
well it's not really causing me any problems at this point
just thought you should know :-)
OK
so I guess I'll leave it on for now, and try to see if I can refine it so that it doesn't affect any other part of the spec
maybe I should instead have my makefile for the multipage build just drop the whole named-character-references table for now
really we just need anolis fixed :-)
strangely enough, I running the multipage build script with the workaround removed, but I'm not getting the errors I was getting before
Hixie: per 2.2.2 Extensibility it follows vendor-specific attributes start with an underscore, but the examples shown above all start with a dash...
man, lots of feature requests in this batch of bugs
Hixie: I tweaked my script to just have the multipage build remove the whole named-character-references table
and also fixed it so that I think you won't need to force your commit
you probably will need to force it the next time you commit
but I think you won't need to after that
MikeSmith: cool
Hixie: copy-paste error in you r4941 commit
http://html5.org/tools/web-apps-tracker?from=4940&to=4941

+
marginheight on body elements
i'll file a bug thanks
hai
Is this the correct place to ask a question about an issue I've run in to when tinkering with Web Sockets?
rjett: sure
I've been having trouble getting my client to connect to my server from my University, but it works everywhere else
Shouldn't Web Sockets get passed any firewall issues?
rjett: which port?
for the Web Socket? I'm using 12345...
can you telnet to that port from your university network?
I couldn't ping my server from the University, but I could access web pages from the server
I did not try to telnet to that port
sounds like you have a proxy that's blocking outgoing connections
i recommend either looking to see if you can use a SOCKS proxy, assuming your browser supports that, or using port 443 and TLS-encrypting the websocket connection
shepazutoo: yt?
Thanks a lot. I really appreciate your help. :)
np
i expect this to be a common problem
From what I had read I was under the impression that Web Sockets would magically handle these kinds of issues
sadly not
quick question, that validator site is a neat idea, but aren't you worried about it getting abused?
the 'address' option in particular
validator site?
http://html5.validator.nu
i was under the impression some one here ran it
abused how?
as in i can make it scan any site i want
how is that different than, say, validator.w3.org?
it's not
i could use that too ;>
but if you're not worried about people using it as an open proxy and attacking other sites, then don't worry about it ;>
i don't really see how they could attack other sites
well, i could easily script up a tool that would point it at a site
then look for common vulnerabilities, such as sql injection
and since i can see the source of the responses
i can just parse out the response
and all of the attacks would look like they are coming from the validator, not from the attacker
i expect henri has set some rate-limiting on the validator
yeah that or some form of a captcha would be good
but yeah i was just curious if anyone thought about it before, so i brought it up.
hsivonen is the guy who runs it, so he's the one to ask
will do, thanks
Hixie: you there?
yeah
notwithstanding the weird <wbr> interaction with nowrap, is it the same as ZWSP?
anyone know?
re: Ruby, I noticed the w3 ruby spec uses annotating WWW with World Wide Web as an example. I’m wondering how using ruby like that relates to the abbr element
relates how?
http://www.w3.org/TR/ruby/
i mean, they're similar... how do you mean?
ruby renders the annotation by default and abbr doesn't, is the main difference
well, if you’re adding ruby to an abbreviation, then I’m guessing that you could also wrap the ruby word in abbr
but the abbr title text would duplicate the rt text, so maybe not necessary
abbr and ruby seem pretty similar, so I guess I’m wondering if there’s any difference apart from the way they display the annotation
hey all
hi Hixie
finally since complex ruby didn’t make it in, would using a title on abbr or span be a way to add the second term
hey JonathanNeal
boblet: well there's lots of differences, e.g. they use different element names, and i wouldn't recommend using <abbr> for annotating bopomofo readings... dunno what to tell you
hey JonathanNeal
hey boblet
boblet: what is the complex ruby example you want to do?
For a while I thought no one could read my messages.  Yay, I exist.
Hixie: ok, I’ll mock up some code and ping you for feedback later
the amount of work required to add a new element to the spec is inane
Hixie: writing an article on it, so referring to the W3 Ruby doc example of Japanese with furigana and romaji
i really need to work on this
boblet: ah
What element are you thinking of adding?
JonathanNeal: it’s the nsfw element
hixie is trying to sneak it in while no one is looking ;-)
trying to turn <wbr> from an obsolete elements into a valid element
it's proving quitethe tedious task
k i think i have it.
regens
Shouldn't that be left to a style?
How is <wbr> meaningful as information?
you can't really do it in style
Hixie: btw, what was the reason complex ruby was dropped? too complex for not enough use cases?
it wasn't dropped
it was just never added
or just deferred til later?
it was not added because IE didn't do it
HTML5's ruby is a reverse engineering of IE's, I didn't pay much attention to the ruby spec
dropped meaning it was specced in the ruby spec
aah
any thoughts of adding it later? say post-HTML5?
are there real use cases for it?
and can those use cases not be handled by simply nesting two rubys in each other?
(i don't know the answers to these questions)
Hixie: I did check what at least some sites use <nobr> for

Hixie: the only one I recall offhand is YouTube, which uses it for the username of the person uploading a video in some screens, presumably because it is atomic and must not be broken across lines, even if it has a space
JonathanNeal: the main use case is the one shown by the example in the spec: http://www.whatwg.org/specs/web-apps/current-work/#the-wbr-element
Hixie: I’ve got some introductory Japanese textbooks that do the kanji with kana and English. will mock up some nested ones and see how I go
othermaciej: sounds like a stylistic concern. If my screen is small, I'd want it to wrap.
prolly not enough use cases to justify complexity
Hixie, checking
Hixie: yeah, I will look around and see if I find any real uses that seem more semantic

boblet: yeah it's a hard call, when there are valid use cases but they are rare... it might just be something to do in a future version, or it might be something we never bother with because it's not that common, or it might be something that there are acceptable workarounds for (like nesting rubys). I'd love to see mockups or photos of real use cases though.
Weeeeird
Niche
it is indeed niche, much like
but since it's already implemented and widely included in tutorials already, it's almost free to support
so since there's a use case, why not
Hixie: do you recall what's partial about the acceptance on <http://www.w3.org/Bugs/Public/show_bug.cgi?id=9350> (the <wbr> bug)?
Hixie: wondering if I should check anything before I mark it CLOSED
othermaciej: just the parenthetical, i think
Hixie: k. also thinking that for non-bopomofo use ruby is almost like a phrase version of small with pre-set styling (“side comments”)
boblet: yeah. it's mostly intended for the CJK typographical ruby thing, the other uses are somewhat esoteric.
othermaciej: i.e. partial acceptance of the argument, not of the change.
I was somewhat surprised by the WWW example
(in W3 Ruby)
yeah me too to be honest
you'll notice the html5 spec doesn't show any such examples
Hixie: I would consider that fully accepted, but fine by me either way
heh
that’s what made me wonder if such examples were legit

othermaciej: to be perfectly honest i marked it partially accepted because i have two buttons, one that says "accepted" and prefills the rationale as concuring with the reporter, and one that says "partially accepted" and leaves the rationale blank, and so since i wanted to write a more detailed rationale, i clicked the second one to save me the selecting the rationale and replacing it :-P
Hixie: lol
boblet: yeah, i dunno. might be worth asking richard ishida or other people more expert in that area what they think.
will do
Oh man ... PeeWee Herman makes me smile.
MikeSmith has quit
There goes HTML5.
umm, just from IRC
There goes IRC.
He is now sleeping :)
There goes being awake.
good morning
There goes it being night.
Heh
Next thing you know <wbr> will be back in the spec.
ok time for bed
nn
Night Hixie!
Hixie: Well, really, we just need Python to be fixed :
why is http://dev.w3.org/csswg/css3-2d-transforms/#transform-property not comma-separated?
mornin'
Hi all!
Anyone here versed in zen html coding?
Where you write HTML like this: a#skip-to-main-content[href=#main-content]
woah, crazy. ruby-position:inline mentioned in #5 Properties Index, but not in #4.1 Ruby Positioning. Wonder how inline differs from right? http://www.w3.org/TR/css3-ruby/
JonathanNeal: I saw a screencast once
I just don't get how you move out of a selector.

Say I want to make

a
JonathanNeal: I’m pretty sure they did multiple blocks in the screencast. I’d guess whitespace (extra returns?)
(parens)
What do you mean by "move out of a selector", JonathanNeal?
"JonathanNeal, This is #html, not #wackyhtmltemplateengines."
tabatkins, I meant I didn't know how to write css that didn't constantly move down the chain
But I realized you can control the scope with parens
nice
JonathanNeal: Um?  You can do what with the who now?
Selectors move down the chain [or forward, with sibling selectors].  That's how they're made.
Are you trying to abuse selectors to do something crazy?
Yes, and I just did.
You've never heard of zen coding?

html>(head>meta[charset=UTF-8]+title)+body>#main-document>(a#skip-to-main-content[href=#main-content])+(header#banner[role=banner]>(hgroup#heading>(h1.site-title[href=@site-url@]>span)+(h2.page-title[href=@page-url@]>span))+(nav#navigation>h1+ul>li*3))+(div#content>(nav#breadcrumbs>(h1>span)+p)+div#main-content)+footer#content-info[role=content-info]>p
That's a complete html5 page with heading, navigation, breadcrumb, content, footer
That looks like a combination of disgusting, unreadable, and ridiculous.
Parentheses don't work like that in CSS.  That looks like a syntax error to me.
If it's meant to be an actual selector.
o_O
it works backward from a selector: serialize a tree matching that ext-CSS
I assume it is just supposed to be some way of generating a document structure
That happens to reuse selector synatx, mostly
is surprised y’all are not up with what the kids are playing with these days
it’s just generating html verbiage from quasi-CSS, to cut down on typing
boblet, like engineer barbie?
Oh, I see.
That seems kind of pointless.  It's not that much shorter.
Although it's true that the redundancy of closing tags in SGML-ish languages is annoying.
annevk: Google is my friend http://www.ni.com/news/releases/april0601.htm ;-)
Reusing selector syntas to make things more readable is an... odd approach
annevk, exactly like engineer barbie
You could of course use sexprs and cut out all the end tags
I've certainly seen that stuff before.  It's just horrifying when extended beyond toy examples.
TextMate does most of it for me, so the only appeal of zen coding is prolly making tables
boblet, it's not a joke anymore I believe, but it doesn't really matter :)
annevk: There’s a computer engineer Barbie, but I can’t find the one with the wrench & grease on her face
that would be a strange computer engineer.
Yeah, who keeps a wrench on their face?
that is not how it works?
No idea.
I use screwdrivers sometimes, but not sure where you'd use a wrench in computing.
In other news I think I have a fix for the spec generation bug
Computer Engineer Barbie; “I ran the measurements on my leg-to-torso ratio against the 95 percentile, and the results are … well…”
Nah, computer engineers son't know statistics
*don't
Computer Engineer Barbie: "I will  be on vacation tomorrow."
is anyone able to dig up that email on default styles for form controls on the WHATWG list?
someone from Google wrote it I believe
(could've been a different list maybe, but I doubt it)
What do we want?  Self Closing DIVS and SPANS!  When do we want them?  NOW!
I'm trying to write a few words about HTML5 forms and it'd be nice to include a pointer to that research
html5 forms seems to be the big thing lately, please link me to that when you're done annevk
I'd love to learn what it is you folks are doing to them.
OK, just updated pms.net
e.g. stuff like http://lists.whatwg.org/htdig.cgi/whatwg-whatwg.org/2009-April/019478.html
cool, specs have to list every browsers behaviour? I figured it was meant to set a standard and hope browsers will addapt
seutje, some specs try that, but they aren't particularly useful to anyone.
HTML5 doesn't try to list every browser's behavior, but it tries to match their behavior when it's consistent.
Or, at any rate, it doesn't require things that it doesn't think implementers will refuse to do.
It tries to specify a single behaviour that, due to legacy, msut be almost the same as existing deployed behaviour from market leaders
At least in cases where sites rely on the behavior.
I see
It would be cool if Simon's html5-elements page could load up individual pages for those elements, instead of having to #get-there
u have a funny way of putting it though
"it doesn't think.."
Which is more cases than you can imagine
the spec became self-aware!
(well it is hopefully as many cases as we can collectively imagine or there will still be cases with required but undefined behaviour)
(so what I really mean is that it is more cases then most people naively imagine)
*than
thought jgraham was going away
Yet he fixed the bug
gsnedders: Maybe I am using my telekinetic powers to bug fix by remotly typing on someone else's keyboard. Maybe it is your keyboard. Have you been watching for unexpected movements?
Well, no.
Tell you what, I fixed the bug so you can fix the tests :)
However, I need to go and cook now ;P
gsnedders, master chef
hmm, that reminds me, shouldn't forget to eat
Hixie: is this the latest? http://dev.w3.org/html5/spec/forms.html#the-select-element
should be
Hixie: I want to add a corner case for handling default-selected item in select element
annevk: http://trac.webkit.org/export/57003/trunk/LayoutTests/fast/forms/select-change-popup-to-listbox.html
it's a bit weird, but all browsers seem to agree, so probably should be spec'd
for size == 1, first item is selected by default
if no other items are selected
but then if you change the size, the default selection is preserved.
annevk: sorry, I did't try on Opera!
no worries
I wonder how mobile browsers deal with this?
http://dev.w3.org/html5/spec/the-xhtml-syntax.html#the-select-element-0
defines UI
i.e. what to render for various values of size
I think it is defined also that the first is selected

"If the multiple attribute is absent, whenever there are no option elements in the select element's list of options that have their selectedness set to true, the user agent must set the selectedness of the first option element in the list of options in tree order that is not disabled, if any, to true."
(that's in section 4.10 again)
annevk: great! do you think it's worth outlining the case of preserving the selectedness when the size changes?
(that's the one I am interested about)
hang on.. reading this one more time :)
I suppose, but that would have to be added to the rendering section; you could add a comment via http://whatwg.org/html#the-select-element-0
(if you fill the thing in at the bottom that will file a bug for you)
(not sure how many other such liveness things there are though and whether they all need to be pointed out; in general nothing changes unless stated otherwise)
So what's so bad about allowing xml style self-closing on all elements?
Or on divs and spans?
Legacy compatibility
JonathanNeal, no existing browser parses them that way in text/html.
And none can change, because there are pages that use the self-closing syntax but actually rely on the fact that it's not self-closing.
I've never been a fan of the term "rely" in that context, because it implies they did it on purpose, when really they just did it, then hacked around it until it sort of worked.
Why do you think reliance is purposeful?
I rely on lots of things that I've never even considered
annevk: actually I think the spec is perfectly fine now that I read it
(read it vs. skim through it)
and I can't think of a better word than "rely" for them
Hmm, not sure what a better term would be.
dglazkov, cool
AryehGregor, so you don't do it so it's more compatible with the old html version?
JonathanNeal, there is no "old HTML version".  HTML5 is the one and only specification to fully specify the details of the text/html format that has been used for years.
ok
All these implementation requirements (or variants there of) were a de facto standard for a long time, now they're becoming de jure.
Previous HTML specs just didn't say anything about error handling by implementations.
So <div /> was non-conforming in HTML prior to XHTML, and browsers consistently ignored the "/" (which was allowed by the HTML specs of the time).
So it's just a property of hypertext to not have self-closing elements?
or bi-closing elements?
The closing "/" was not valid in any version of HTML prior to XHTML 1.0.
It's an XML feature, not a text/html feature.
It would raise validation errors if you used it, which no one did, because it did nothing anyway.
XHTML allowed the self-closing feature, but browsers didn't implement it in text/html for compatibility reasons.
And still don't, and presumably never will.

Actually it wouldn't raise validation errors, because SGML-based HTML4 parsers (e.g. validator.w3.org) consider
to be correct and equivalent to
> or whatever it is
Right, and there is meta and link too
and img
It's never meant "self-closing" in non-X HTML
Oh, really?  Interesting.
SHORTTAG and NET are relevant keywords
http://lists.whatwg.org/htdig.cgi/whatwg-whatwg.org/2004-August/001940.html
(The W3C validator does warn about these things now, though)

So
are bad?
No
Why would they be?
Ah, so it's because they're NOT self-closing, right?
I have no idea what you're talking about :-)
is okay because it's not an element that opens and closes, it just is.

You've always been able to write "
" and "" in HTML, because that's how the syntax is defined
JonathanNeal: In old-style SGML, the / was a way of closing a tag without explicitly using the end tag.

So ...
is also valid.
So what would be bad about <div /> then?

So you could, frex, do "
stuff goes here/" and be equivalent to "
stuff goes here
"
not quite
<div/stuff goes here/
or <br/ (since there's no end tag, no end / either)
Ah yeah, right.
No > ?
Nope.
the first / takes places of the / and the next / takes place of the entire end tag
er
let me retype that
Which means that, if browsers were conforming SGML parsers, you'd see a linebreak followed by a > character in your page.
the first / takes place of the > and the next / takes place of the entire end tag
Wow!  That's not implemented that way in any browser, is it?
No, browsers don't actually implement SGML.
there's a reason html5 gives up on the sgml fiction :-)
So, you can do <div /> because it wouldn't be properly conforming to something no browsers actually implement?
*can't
No, you can't do <div /> because it looks exactly like "<div>" to all browsers.
Well, in HTML4.
[That is, it looks like an open tag.]
here, if you want to blow your mind: http://damowmow.com/playground/mental.html http://damowmow.com/playground/not-html-yet-valid.html
both of those validate in an html4 validator
Html nothing.  I'm talking about browsers here, not languages.  All existing browsers, current and legacy, treat it like that.
[Unless they are specifically in an XHTML mode, of course.[

So allowing
as a short form of
wouldn't be backwards compatible in any relevant browser straight away, let alone all the pages that accidentally use
and would be screwed up if it actually acted like
.
wonders when the SGML interest will die off
Dammit, JonathanNeal.  I didn't realize you'd dropped, and typed several lines at you.  >_<
tabatkins, not only did i drop
my whole computer restarted
That's fun.
hixie's links really blew my mind
and lappy's.
Anyway, check the logs.  I don't want to retype those.
I was like "This is a cell" and my computer was like "this fuuuuuuuuuuuuuuu"
Where do I find the logs?
tabatkins: There's this fancy new concept known as "copy and paste" which you could use
Check the topic.
Philip`: Too fancy for me.
checking
tabatkins, aren't nav and video not backwards compatible?
I believe <section> causes fuglies in ff2 and ie6-7-8
They have fallback.
they don't have fallback ... not in those browsers.  What do you mean by "fallback"?
ff2 is luckily ignorable.
ie6-8 has the hack, which is nice.
so it's okay because there's a hack? :-|
The hack makes it usable *now*, so... yes?  Things are a lot less appealing when there's no way to use them until all browsers update.
That doesn't mean we'll avoid *all* things without fallback, but they need a better reason to exist.
Self-closing syntax has no real reason to exist besides "It's what XML does."
ie supports it.
No it doesn't
except sometimes
ie's parsing behaviour is seriously messed up
and very internally inconsistent
like in unknown elements that are recognised due to being declared with xmlns:foo or with the createElement hack, or due to being any normal unknown element in IE9
(i.e. <section/> closes the element in IE9)
(but <div/> doesn't)
Ah, I see.
I tried This is <span style="background: #0F0; padding: 10px;" /> self closing. and it failed in all browsers.
So it can't be implemented because it would break on all browsers.  You're lucky you got any new elements in :)
Considering how ff used to handle these things.
If FF still handles unknown elements as badly as it used to, I suspect the new elements would have had a much more uphill battle.
aye
goes to learn himself a python for great justice.
is it really possible that Firefox still has no support for websockets? Just downloaded the newest version 3.6.3, but the included websocket chat in Jetty fails to run
mr_daniel, https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=472529
Work ongoing.
mr_daniel: websockets isn't really ready yet, the wg is still discussing the protocol
Philip`, apparently their plan was to conform to HTML5
Philip`, maybe you should file bugs?
mr_daniel: if you are comfortable building from sources, you can download the patch from that bug and apply it and build and it should work
Hixie: it seems ready enough for experimenting with at least
and for playing Quake2
MikeSmith: we're making non-backwards-compatible changes to the protocol, so everything will break
Hixie: yeah, I realize
but it's understandable that people are anxious to try it out in the mean time in spite of any instability of the protocol spec
sure, i've done it myself :-)
in my spare time i'm writing a web-based mud using websockets
mud?
multi-user d...?
daemon
Hixie: you should make a mud where the character is a spec editor who needs to try to create spec for Web-platform features and get them standardized and implemented
heh
annevk: multi-user dungeon
oops. :x   http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/MUD
thought it was "domain"
reads annevk blog and finds out about https://wiki.mozilla.org/User:Mounir.lamouri/HTML5_Forms
would be interesting to know how soon active work might get started on all the items in the red rows
oh, I see that some of them do have bugs associated with them already
I wonder if anybody knows/remembers how long it took Opera engineering to finish their implementation of Web Forms 2 at the time
or how many people-hours it took
wonders if recent TC39 f2f spent any time discussing https://cvs.khronos.org/svn/repos/registry/trunk/public/webgl/doc/spec/TypedArray-spec.html or other related proposals
one person on and off for half a year or so?
doesn't remember the details
annevk: ok
it seems like Webkit devs have been working on it very actively for more than 6 months now
btw, http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/MUD
it could be one person for a year on and off
but not more than a year and not more than one person developing; I created tests together with someone else
ok
but then our UI is not great...
but then WebKit does not have UI yet I believe...
oh well
I guess it's hard to decide what's the appropriate UI for some of these controls
btw, W3C Bugzilla instance was upgraded today
A decent rule, of course, is "Do whatever the most popular equivalent jQuery plugin does."
well, you need a UI engineer, not someone who's typically deeply involved in DOM/parsing/etc. code
right, exactly
i've been doing some testing of the various form elements in recent browser releases. webkit seems to understand from a DOM perspective new input types, but does nothing with them
WebKit's UI for many of the controls is not so great
in terms of UI
estellevw, yeah, that is somewhat troublesome
estellevw, but as long as nobody ships final releases I guess it could work
no, i have been testing the actual releases, not the nightly builds... so it is what has been released
annevk: or even not just a UI engineer, but a UX expert too
just a little insight might have done wonders, but we were short on time too
and with no competition and not much real world usage we didn't move it beyond experimental
estellevw, i.e. in Safari 4 and Chrome 4?
for example, chrome supports color, date and email, but doesn't validate
yeah, but all told, it's still a pretty good implementation
yeah, exactly
ugh :/
MikeSmith, yeah, it's pretty cool
Hixie: W3C bugzilla is down
i've been compiling results here: http://www.standardista.com/html5/html5-web-forms (not finished ... a work in progress)
Hixie: systems team is working on it

also, http://www.miketaylr.com/code/html5-forms-ui-support.html
MIke- i came across your site last week, and found it extremely useful
ahh, k
and then started visually comparing
yeah i'm just doing feature testing
so, assumed DOM support from your excellent resource, and then sandboxed each
nice to virtually meet you, by the way
same

so it is only the 192.168.* range

but that appears to lead nowhere
MikeSmith, the actual archive is now at  http://mail.apps.ietf.org/ietf/charsets/
MikeSmith, just wondering why the W3C one was not kept updated
annevk: dunno, I'll ask RIchard
Hixie: Did you try regenning the spec recently? Did the non-BMP entity problems go away?
jgraham: fwiw, I can try it now

A question, In CSS3 the display property refers to block/inline elements http://www.w3.org/TR/css3-layout/#declaring-templates-the-display-property but HTML5 does not define block/inline elements. Is there something I am missing?
and they're rubbish compared to mouse+keyboard for FPSes anyway
divya: In terms of CSS, a block/inline element is one which has display:block/inline set on it in the default UA stylesheet.
divya, look in the rendering section.
http://www.whatwg.org/specs/web-apps/current-work/multipage/rendering.html#rendering
tabatkins: so does this mean display no longer alters the "content model" of an element?
a block/inline element in CSS is one which has display:block/inline as its computed value, not necessarily in the UA style sheet
divya: it never did
Hixie is more correct than I was.  I was referring to what elements were by default.
technically even its _used_ style, not computed style, though i think with 'display' they're always the same
(or does 'position' not affect the computed style?)
an element with display:inline;position:absolute is block-level
ok yeah for such an element the computed value is 'block'
so yes, computed value

Hixie: I was under the illusion display can alter the content model because of this sentence in the HTML4.01 spec http://www.w3.org/TR/html401/struct/global.html#h-7.5.3 "Style sheets provide the means to specify the rendering of arbitrary elements, including whether an element is rendered as block or inline. "
Rendered as a block or inline, yes.  That doesn't change what kind of elements are legal to put inside of it, though.
divya: yeah, that confusion is why i stopped using "block" and "inline" in html5
it confused a lot of people
you're not alone, by a long shot :-)
Hixie: thanks, that is a comfort :)
so in a sense display:inline/block are legacy CSS syntaxes with no real-world relationship with the elements?
I'm not sure what you mean by "legacy" or "real-world" there.  CSS has no interaction with what's legal or illegal in HTML.
that's not how i would put it
i'd just say display:inline/block conrtol the rendering
and that's all :-)
ok that makes sense :)
(I think it is hard for me to not get confused between css inline/block and html4 inline/block)
Easiest is to probably just ignore the HTML4 definitions entirely.  ^_^
tabatkins: :)
I bet that's why HTML5 doesn't use those terms to begin with.
I wonder why not many people brought this up. :/
(when they were writing their "Top Ten CSS Tricks" posts)
Why would they bring it up?
AryehGregor: It is confusing and deserves clarity. More than cool tricks that can be accomplished with display: inline/block
i found the distinction of block, inline and flow very helpful to understanding the semantics of elements
has no idea what to do about character references that don't end with ;
Hixie, are they used too much to just be dropped?
yes
there are bugs that ask for various changes to the way they're parsed
or reported as errors
we could make unescaped & not be an error but leave charrefs that don't have a ; be an error, i guess
so "?a=b&c=d" would be fine
how do you tell the difference?
but "?apple=banana&copy=ditto" would be an error (since the &copy gets parsed in an unexpected way)
oh, so from the fixed list of known entities
or we could make &copy= not be parsed as a char ref in attributes
just like &copypasta already isn't
but that makes attributes even more different than content
Are we sure that char references without a trailing ; appear in attributes, especially @href and similar, often enough to cause a problem?
tabatkins: cause problems in which direction?
In the direction of, if we make them not parse as entities, links will break.

tabatkins: i expect there are plenty of pages that say "?foo=bar&copy=ditto" and are broken, and i expect there are plenty of pages that say "this file &copy 2010 by me" and expect it to be an entity.
Sure.
the latter is even valid in ghtml4
s/g//
so yes, things will break if we change anything, and things are broken if we don't change anything
I think I'm fine with attributes being different from content here.
i'm only talking about attributes here
they're already different than content, so that ship has sailed -- teh question is whether we can keep that to a minimum, so that people moving stuff in and out of attributes don't get screwed
i'd really like to make any valid content in one have the same meaning in the other
invalid content is less of an issue
I'd like links to be easy to author, and not have to worry about the names of my query paramaters.
It's too bad we can't just make &copy equivalent to &copy in content as well.
But the extra difference between content and attributes seems like the lesser evil here.
It's not like it should come up very often in practice.
You could make "&copy" and such raise a warning or error if used in content.
It would be interesting to try and see how much outcry there is (try making entities require a ;, and allow unescaped & otherwise).

Yeah, I wonder if implementers would do that.  How many pages are we talking about?  It wouldn't be huge breakage in any case, if it's largely in copyright boilerplate then most users probably won't even notice.
(even if they view an affected page)
wonders why tabatkins has decapitalized himself
Indeed.
we're talking billions of pages here
Eh, accidental.  irssi is taking my account name from linux, and I'm not bothering to correct it.
AryehGregor: it would be a disaster in non-english locales
Oh well.
e.g. &egrave is one of these entities
suggests the simplest option to improve compatibility on the web is to make = make these entities not get replaced
er, http://www.w3.org/Bugs/Public/show_bug.cgi?id=9207#c5 suggests
= and _, apparently.
That sounds like a clever solution.
_ was not quite as clear
ok let's add = and then reexamine the conformance problem.
i suppose i could make &foo= be not a parse error in attributes, but otherwise leave these rules alone
or i could just make all &foo that don't match an entity be not parse errors
the latter seems simpler, though it would lead to authors never bothering to escape their &s, which could get them in trouble if they accidentally walk into &s
this would make &foo; (where "foo" isn't anything known) into _not_ an error...
Hixie: I demand a recount
can you point me to the place where the spec says that if the size of select is >1, multiple is not set, and no options have selectedness set to true, we shouldn't mark any item as selected?
no, because the spec doesn't say that :-)

"If the multiple attribute is absent, whenever there are no option elements in the select element's list of options that have their selectedness set to true, the user agent must set the selectedness of the first option element in the list of options in tree order that is not disabled, if any, to true."
but all browser that I know of do it.
do what?
not select if size > 1
annevk told me to do the comment thingy
should I go ahead and do it?
how weird
why would size="" have any effect on this?
please do file a bug
it's an easy fix
i wonder why browsers act like this
Hixie, dglazkov: I suspect the browser rule is "if it renders as a pop-up menu select the first item, if it renders as a listbox, don't select anything"
because listboxes have a reasonable "nothing selected" state
othermaciej: yes, something like that
that would be why size= has an effect
but if you change the size from X to 1 and then back to X (X>1), you'll have a selected element.
sure, because size changes don't cause the selected element to be deselected
but they do cause the element to be selected :)
and browsers don't keep track of whether something got selected by default
yep
is writing a layout test for that
yes, if you enter the "must have a selection" state (no multiple or size > 1), then an item gets default-selected
but when you leave that state, nothing gets deselected
seems logical to me, at least to the extent one can expect logic of the Web platform
i guess it makes sense given visual UAs using different widgets and how single-select list boxes can have an (normally unreachable) no-selection state
doesn't make much sense from an abstract point of view though
